Pit_Observation.pitNotes: During the ECT, I cut down 120cm to isolate the back of the block. After the test (ECTP30@down60cm) I pulled the block off and another 65-35cm block from below came with. The intial propgation had stepped down in a non-planer shear to the stiff slab below.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Avalanche broke around 64 cm either above or below the crust (unsure). It broke into deeper layers in a few places. Slope angle of this area is mostly under 35 degrees with just a few steeper rollovers. Very stong winds in mid January created such a hard layer that tied this whole area together. We suspect this avalnache happened on Saturday or Sunday, Jan 20 or 21.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit Score of 7
Vindutsatt liten formation. Sten. Drevsnö från tisdagen.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Collapsing, localized;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Widespread persistent weak layer that remains active on all aspects with exception of due S. This SE aspect was more reactive than a nearby slope a week ago. We have received 1.2" of SWE since then. Failure consistently occurs on top of the December drought layer, but once triggered, avlalanche will likely go to the ground. Slope collapsed as we walked on to it.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Moderate ridge top speeds from the NE. ECT broke on 23 taps in top 20cm before propagation.
Observers: CL and JV Objective: determine new snow FC interface Plotted: CL
Open trees.

Pit dug near the top the second bowl, right about at the skiers boundary to the Mt. A resort. Noted that there had been significant wind loading in this area from prevailing winds from he south over the last week. There were noted instabilities in the snowpack but overall it seems to be consolidating into a healthier, more cohesive snopack. Weak layers do have the potential to trigger some slides on these slopes and the surface was harboring surface hoar crystals on its surface well into the day, which may pose problems into the future.
Snow Pack was 205 CM deep. Noted wind loading.
Brottkantprofil för Na2 18.1.24.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Checking for reactivity or bonding with the tracking PWL on an aspect that receives higher solar input. There are still noted isolated regions where these facets are still proving to harbor.

Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Collapsing, widespread; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Numerous collapses as we worked across this slope at the upper edge of treeline. Pit dug in an area that collapsed with a 2 meter radius (visible cracks around perimeter). Other collapses propagated up to 5 meters. HS highly variable 60-100cm near this pit location. All pits in this area failed and propagated at the JAN 4 interface between the December Drought Snow and the new snow that had fallen since JAN 4, 2024. This pit had a Grom Score of 2.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Site chosen to represent wind-loaded slopes at treeline. Pit site adjacent to trees, but in a wind-loaded location. Average HS in the trees was 45-50 cm with ski penetration almost to the ground. HS at Mayflower Gulch TH was 60cm. No whumpfing or cracking - hard slab layers were protecting the weak foundation on this slope. I wouldn't be excited for a steeper or bigger slope with similar stratigraphy.

Just outside Ski Area Boundary in unaffected snow, ran out of time to perform more stability tests.

The late December crust is thoroughly faceted and less dense than the snow above and below. The two mid December crusts are faced, but you can still see the shape of the old melt forms. These two lower crusts are denser than the fasted snow above and below.
Measured 9.55 inches of total SWE with the slab making up 3.37 inches of that total
TL open feature previously unskiied.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Remotely triggered yesterday by a snowboarder.
Looking for prevalence and reactivity of December drought layer on southerly aspects. We are finding it on SE and SW with ECT scores in the low to mid 20's. Due S was not reactive nor as pervasive.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Light winds at pit location. Moderate to intense snow transport observed at ridgeline.
Snowpit below small cornices above the bowl between Judah and Donner Peak. Regular wind deposit in this location.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit location adjacent to size 2.5 Mr on Jan. 10. Also same slope as size 1.5 Sa incident with a partial burial on Jan. 7. Bed surface of both slides was the MFcr/FC interface down 79cm. Suspect the MFcr is a laminate of both the Dec. 20 and Dec. 30 crusts.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Although we found no results on the ECT, we decided to play it safe and not ski the obviously loaded, 40+ degree slope below us. Took two runs in Drain Pool, did not observe any obvious signs of instability during the decent (other than some sluff). At the end of the second run, we triggered a propgating collapse down 80cm on the edge of a windloaded, convex rollover on a similiar aspect to the slope we wanted to ski. The mountains do not provide direct feedback very often, today was one of those rare days.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Collapsing, widespread; Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Open meadow near forested area, shaded to southern exposure, near top of lift line and West Bench trail. In proximity to surface water which could affect results. Measured very large surface hoar in the general area prior to storm cycle which could be the layer the ECT propagated on.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Checking in on a PWL of buried surface hoar that has proven to be a weak layer in a snowpack full of odd crusts and faceting snow. Pit dug at the entrance of Wongs Trail entering the mid elevation of the 1st chute in the Mt. Ashland Bowl.

Collapsing, widespread;
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug a pit a couple of bowls west of Kangaroo the run. Location was well protected and snow surface was mildly wind effected. Most notable layer on this day was the 1.7cm thick punchable rain crust. I ran out of time to run stability tests. Based on stratigraphy I would imagine that snowpack in this location on this day was nonreactive.
